On Tuesday 30 September 2003 16:43, Jim Dixon wrote:

> I know that this is official Sun doctrine.  But compilation is always
> a lossy process, and the smaller the target instruction set, the more
> information you lose.  The JVM has a small instruction set.  To increment
> a variable, you put a 1 on the stack and say "add".  Oh my :-(

So what?

While they haven't run as JITs, I have written compiler back-ends that take
stackish code and destack it to at least some extent. Turning

    load local x; load 1; add; store local x

into

    add Rx, Rx, 1   [ARM, 'cos I don't speak x86]

when local x can be put into a register is not hard, especially if someone's
paying you to do it.

RTL/2's intermediate code was stackish (two stacks, one for addresses,
one for values, not necessarily nested, ugh), but the SMR-mu back end
I-and-others wrote for it regularly turned the sequence for "add 1 to 
thingy" into some appropriate compact non-stacky code.

Yes, compilation can be a lossy process. But JVM bytecode isn't very
lossy compared to the source, partly because of the requirement for
bytecode verification. You can do a pretty good code code reconstruction,
as existing decompilers demonstrate.

Now, how much of that effort you want to stuff into a JIT, that's a legitimate
concern. But optimising x += 1 is, I would have said, a no-brainer.

-- 
Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
